title: What’s playing on Broadway right now?
description: From new shows like “MJ” and “A Strange Loop” to long-running Tony Award winners, our guide breaks down everything you need to navigate Broadway.
content: From new shows like “MJ” and “A Strange Loop” to long-running Tony Award winners, our guide breaks down everything you need to navigate Broadway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Colin
title: Taking On Fast Fashion by Taking It Down
description: The organizer Hoda Katebi is tackling the global garment industry, not as a reformer but as an abolitionist.
content: Visionaries is a limited series that looks at figures who are trying to transform the way we live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: After 36 years, another Marcos may lead the Philippines.
description: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has spent decades defending his family’s name against accusations of corruption and downplaying his father’s brutal regime.
content: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has waited a long time for this moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Jenny Gross, Vivian Giang and Anna Schaverien
title: Why the Stock Market Keeps Plunging
description: The financial markets are coming to grips with the Federal Reserve’s policy change, as geopolitical factors complicate the outlook for the global economy.
content: The S&P 500 has now registered five consecutive weekly declines, its longest streak of losses since June 2011. Stocks rallied earlier last week, before suffering their largest-single day drop since the start of the pandemic on Thursday. Futures point to another drop in U.S. stocks this morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘A Strange Loop’ Nominated for 11 Tonys as Broadway Lauds Comeback
description: “The Lehman Trilogy,” as well as revivals of “Company” and “For Colored Girls,” led in their respective categories as the industry tries to recover from the long pandemic shutdown.
content: A musical about making art and a play about making money dominated the Tony Awards nominations Monday, as Broadway sought to celebrate its best work and revive its fortunes after the lengthy and damaging coronavirus shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Jan Ransom
title: Rikers Officers Lagged in Helping 3 Detainees Who Died, Report Finds
description: In each case, fellow inmates struggled to help when jail officers did not, according to the Board of Correction, which expressed “extreme” concern in its report.
content: Herman Diaz was eating an orange in a Rikers Island jail on March 18 when he began to choke.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Shanghai Gets a Taste of Xinjiang
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 9, 2022.
content: “The pandemic did a huge favor to the Chinese Communist Party, which took the opportunity to expand its power infinitely.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Hot Dog as Art, New York Style
description: The artist Steve Marcus will display his collection of hot dog art, alongside his own work, through Nov. 6.
content: Steve Marcus, an artist who lives and works on the Lower East Side, has been collecting New York hot dog memorabilia for years. Some of his trove, along with his own cartoon works, will be on display at the Museum at Eldridge Street through Nov. 6. He will speak at the opening reception, Thursday from 6 to 9 p.m., which will be open to the public free of charge with a reservation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: A Marcos Victory?
description: Plus the resignation of Sri Lanka’s prime minister and Taiwan’s pandemic pivot.
content: With more than 90 percent of election returns counted in a preliminary tally, Ferdinand Marcos Jr. appeared sure to win the country’s presidential election early Tuesday morning. He has a huge lead over Leni Robredo in the Philippines’ most consequential vote in recent history. Here are live updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Stock market’s plunge continues on new concerns about global economy.
description: New data from China is adding to worries over high inflation, rising interest rates and supply chain disruptions.
content: Wall Street’s relentless decline stretched into a sixth week on Monday, fueled by new data from China that added to concerns about a global economy that’s being battered by high inflation, rising interest rates and a malfunctioning supply chain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: In Photos: Russia Celebrates Victory Day Holiday With Parade in Red Square
description: President Vladimir V. Putin used his speech on Russia’s most important secular holiday to rally support for the country’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: Russia held its annual Victory Day military parade in Moscow’s Red Square on Monday to honor the Soviet victory over Nazi Germany in World War II. This year’s traditional parade featured 11,000 participants and 131 armored vehicles. President Vladimir V. Putin used a speech delivered from his rostrum near the Lenin Mausoleum to try and turn Russian pride in the 1945 victory into increased support for what he has called the “special military operation” in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Adams Defends Police for Handcuffing Vendor Who Sold Mangoes in Subway
description: “Next day, it’s propane tanks being on the subway system. The next day, it’s barbecuing,” the mayor said after María Falcon was detained in Brooklyn for selling fruit.
content: Mayor Eric Adams on Monday defended police officers who last month handcuffed a woman accused of selling fruit without a license in a Brooklyn subway station, saying mango sales could pave the way for bigger problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Pasick
title: Victory Day without a victory
description: Vladimir Putin tries to channel Russia’s World War II pride into support for the invasion of Ukraine.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: Pamela Anderson, Amber Heard and the Limits of the Feminist Redemption Plot
description: There’s nothing quite like rewatching a woman’s life collapse in the name of righting history.
content: To look the part of Pamela Anderson in “Pam & Tommy,” the Hulu series, the actress Lily James sat through four hours of makeup each day and reportedly went through 50 pairs of 34DD prosthetic breasts, which had to be switched out repeatedly during filming and were at times so sweaty, they almost fell off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: The Tony nominations are being announced right now.
description: As the theater industry continues its attempt to rebound after its lengthy pandemic shutdown, the industry this morning began its effort to celebrate the best work on Broadway by announcing a new set of Tony nominees.
content: As the theater industry continues its attempt to rebound after its lengthy pandemic shutdown, the industry this morning began its effort to celebrate the best work on Broadway by announcing a new set of Tony nominees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and Kashmir Hill
title: Clearview AI settles suit and agrees to limit sales of facial recognition database.
description: The facial recognition software maker is largely prohibited from selling its database of photos to private companies.
content: Clearview AI, the facial recognition software maker, on Monday settled a lawsuit brought by the American Civil Liberties Union and agreed to limit its face database in the United States primarily to government agencies and not allow most American companies to have access to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1 Million Homes in California
description: A storybook house in Fullerton, a midcentury ranch in Calistoga and a three-bedroom condominium unit in Los Angeles.
content: This house is less than two miles from downtown Fullerton, a charming commercial district where Spanish-style buildings house restaurants, bars and boutiques. It is a 10-minute drive from the campus of California State University, Fullerton, which has the largest student enrollment of any school in the Cal State system.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pulitzer Prizes 2022: A Guide to the Winning Books and Finalists
description: Joshua Cohen’s novel “The Netanyahus” won the fiction prize, and the Times reporter Andrea Elliott won the general nonfiction award for “Invisible Child.”
content: Fifteen books were recognized as winners or finalists for the Pulitzer Prize on Friday, in the categories of fiction, general history, biography, poetry and general nonfiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Long a Journeyman Backup, Suddenly a Star of the N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Louis Domingue, once the Penguins’ third-string goalie and now its starter, has become a cult hero in Pittsburgh, leading the team to a 2-1 series lead over the Rangers.
content: PITTSBURGH — The school bus drivers along Chemin Authier in Mont-St.-Hilaire, Quebec, knew Louis Domingue was not going to move his nets for them. There was a school at the end of the cul-de-sac, and in order for the legion of buses to get by Domingue’s nets, the drivers were forced to maneuver around them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Clarissa Ward: ‘Fear and Panic Are Bedfellows’ in Ukraine
description: CNN’s chief international correspondent talks about covering the Russia-Ukraine war.
content: Clarissa Ward has had, as she puts it, a “long and very complicated relationship” with Russia. The chief international correspondent for CNN, she has had stints in Moscow since the beginning of her career, and has struggled to get a Russian visa since she investigated the 2020 poisoning of the Russian opposition leader Aleksei Navalny.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Politico’s publication of the Supreme Court draft falls into a hazy area of press protections.
description: The Supreme Court is grappling with one of the most significant disclosures of a government secret in half a century: the release of a draft opinion that sets the framework for overturning Roe v. Wade, writes The New York Times’s Jeremy Peters.
content: The Supreme Court is grappling with one of the most significant disclosures of a government secret in half a century: the release of a draft opinion that sets the framework for overturning Roe v. Wade, writes The New York Times’s Jeremy Peters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Whitmer
title: I’m a Pro-Choice Governor, and I’m Not Going to Sit on My Hands Waiting for Congress
description: A novel Michigan lawsuit will attempt to continue to make abortion available.
content: As I read the U.S. Supreme Court’s draft opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, I was devastated. It was shocking to see, laid out in cold legalese, the blatant ideological reasoning gutting the constitutional right to abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: draconian
description: This word has appeared in 146 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word draconian has appeared in 146 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 18 in “You Asked, We Answered: How Can You Get a Better Night’s Sleep?” by Joanne Chen:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Full List of the 2022 Tony Award Nominees
description: On Monday, the nominees for the 75th Tony Awards were announced. The ceremony will take place on June 12 on CBS and Paramount+.
content: Follow our live updates of the 2022 Tony Awards nominations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Pulitzer Prizes Spotlight Jan. 6 Capitol Riot and Mideast Air Wars Coverage
description: The New York Times won multiple awards, and The Washington Post won the prestigious public service category for its reporting on the attack on the Capitol.
content: The Pulitzer Prizes were awarded on Monday to an array of news organizations for investigations that uncovered the tragic toll of the United States’ air war in the Middle East, exposed the dangers of a Tampa lead smelter and pieced together the full picture of the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Madonna and Beeple Collaborate on NFT Project
description: The pop singer spent the last year working with the digital artist on a video series about motherhood. Proceeds will benefit three nonprofits.
content: Has Madonna embraced the blockchain?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Anybody Can Dribble a Basketball. But Few Can Do It Like This.
description: Three elite dribblers of the past — God Shammgod, Tim Hardaway and Oscar Robertson — share their secrets, and name their favorites now.
content: There’s hardly a more exciting play in basketball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Commemorations against a backdrop of war.
content: Despite the World War II commemorations in most of Europe yesterday and in Russia today, there is no indication that the war in Ukraine is anywhere near ending. In the 77 years since the end of World War II, the possibility of a broad conflagration in Europe has seldom seemed more plausible. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: ‘If Economists Are So Smart, Why Ain’t They Rich?’
description: Here are five theories.
content: After I wrote a newsletter last month on how economists’ views differ from those of ordinary people, I got emails to the effect of, “If economists are so smart, why ain’t they rich?” I’m not an economist, so the question doesn’t ruffle my feathers. The possible explanations, though, are interesting — sometimes funny, sometimes kind of deep. Here are five theories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Don’t Be Fooled by His Smile. Tyrese Maxey Can Ball.
description: Maxey, the second-year Philadelphia 76ers guard, is showing a maturity beyond his 21 years during the playoffs. And the Sixers need him.
content: Many of the key members of the Philadelphia 76ers have become jaded by the realities of life in the N.B.A.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: In a Chaotic Tonys Season, It Was an Honor Just to Open
description: The Tony nominations spread the wealth among many worthy (and a few unworthy) productions, as if to salute them for arriving at all.
content: If the roster of Tony Award nominees announced on Monday looks even odder and more random than usual, well, it’s been an odd and random season. For that matter, it wasn’t even really a season. The surfeit of nods — many categories that usually feature five nominations this year feature six or seven — pales in comparison to the scope of eligible productions, the first of which (“Girl From the North Country”) opened in March 2020, just before the pandemic blew an 18-month hole in Broadway. If my math is correct, that was 100 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: As a ‘Seismic Shift’ Fractures Evangelicals, an Arkansas Pastor Leaves Home
description: Kevin Thompson thought he would lead his hometown church for the rest of his life. Then came Trump and everything after.
content: FORT SMITH, Ark. — In the fall of 2020, Kevin Thompson delivered a sermon about the gentleness of God. At one point, he drew a quick contrast between a loving, accessible God and remote, inaccessible celebrities. Speaking without notes, his Bible in his hand, he reached for a few easy examples: Oprah, Jay-Z, Tom Hanks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos and Erika P. Rodriguez
title: Solar Power Offers Puerto Ricans a Lifeline but Remains an Elusive Goal
description: The island’s energy grid has struggled to recover after Hurricane María almost wiped it out in 2017. While solar-power systems can fill gaps, they aren’t cheap.
content: As Puerto Rico reeled from its worst power outage in months, one that left virtually all of the island’s 1.5 million customers without electricity for days, the town of Adjuntas was an oasis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: Eggs Do It All
description: Fry them until they’re crisp and runny, boil them as a speedy snack or whip them into billowing clouds with these 24 recipes.
content: It can be difficult to get Quentin Compson — my 10-year-old, wire-haired rescue dog — to rise from her bed. But one guaranteed way is to boil an egg. The second I break open that shell, I know that I can look down at my feet and see her standing right there, tail wagging, waiting for a bite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas Martin
title: Midge Decter, an Architect of Neoconservatism, Dies at 94
description: As a writer and intellectual, she abandoned liberal politics, challenged the women’s movement and championed the Reagan Republican agenda.
content: Midge Decter, a writer and editor who abandoned liberalism to help lay the intellectual foundation for the neoconservative movement and the so-called culture wars over feminism, gay rights and other social issues, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Jones
title: These Bats Buzz Like Hornets to Scare Off Predators
description: Scientists say they have discovered the first case of mammals mimicking insects to defend themselves from being eaten.
content: To scare off potential predators, some animals display the traits of more deadly creatures. A scarlet kingsnake, for example, wears a red, black and yellow striped pattern similar to that of a venomous coral snake; innocuous butterfly species display the same beautiful splashes of color on their wings as their noxious relatives; and nestlings of species of Amazonian bird are thought to avoid predation by exhibiting the movement and bright orange hue of a toxic caterpillar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: The Woman Steering Russia’s War Economy
description: Elvira Nabiullina got another five-year term as head of Russia’s central bank after quelling the initial market panic over the invasion of Ukraine.
content: For the second time in less than a decade, Elvira Nabiullina is steering Russia’s economy through treacherous waters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: How Elizabeth Olsen Came Into Her Powers
description: The actress started as an indie darling and never expected to become a Marvel linchpin as Wanda Maximoff. But she’s now so invested in the role, she’s open to a solo film.
content: Elizabeth Olsen is used to waiting in the wings. When she was an acting student at New York University, she landed an understudy role in the Broadway play “Impressionism,” starring Jeremy Irons. The show ran for 56 performances. Olsen didn’t take the stage a single time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: ‘Know that it’s possible’: L Morgan Lee on her trailblazing Tony nomination.
description: The actress made theater history, becoming the first openly transgender performer to be nominated for a Tony Award for her work in “A Strange Loop.”
content: L Morgan Lee made theater history on Monday, becoming what  production officials described as the first openly transgender performer to be nominated for a Tony Award for her performance as a featured actress in “A Strange Loop.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Kenneally
title: The Limits of Biological Psychiatry
description: In “The Mind and the Moon,” Daniel Bergner explores how much we know — and how much we don’t — about mental health.
content: In a workshop run by the Hearing Voices Network, the journalist Daniel Bergner — a contributing writer at The New York Times Magazine — participated in a mock job interview. He sat across from a pretend employer who asked all the usual questions: What was Bergner’s work experience? What were his hobbies? All the while, another participant whispered down a long tube made of wrapping paper into Bergner’s ear: Careful what you say. Careful what you say about your background. Bergner couldn’t think straight. The interviewer continued: Was Bergner a team player? The whispery voice kept on: Careful what you say about your background. The exercise didn’t last long. For Bergner, the dark warnings went from incredibly distracting to totally irresistible, and he gave up, rather than yell “Shut up” at the voice that only he could hear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: A Coming Fall Surge?
description: U.S. officials predict another 100 million cases in late 2022.
content: The Biden administration is preparing for the possibility that 100 million Americans will be infected with the coronavirus this fall and winter, according to an administration official. That’s lower than the number of Americans who were infected during the Omicron wave in December and January, but still amounts to roughly 30 percent of the U.S. population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus J. Moore
title: At 85, the Jazz Bassist Ron Carter Still Seeks ‘A Better Order of Notes’
description: The famously curious musician and bandleader will celebrate his milestone birthday with a career-spanning Carnegie Hall concert.
content: On a recent morning on the Upper West Side, the bassist and bandleader Ron Carter sat on the far end of a plush, rust-colored sofa in his spacious 10th floor apartment, an oak-hued space with ornate sculptures and panoramic views of the bustling neighborhood blocks below. In the background wafted a gentle melody from Antônio Carlos Jobim, the Brazilian multi-instrumentalist and a former collaborator. The place exuded a grandeur that describes the man, too. It’s no surprise that Carter — Mr. Carter, Maestro, a jazz legend — lives here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Ex-Deputy Sheriff Is Charged With Being a ‘Wedding Crasher Bandit’
description: Landon Rankin, a retired deputy, stole boxes of cards containing cash and checks from 11 weddings in the Phoenix area, the authorities said.
content: A retired deputy sheriff became a “wedding crasher bandit,” turning up neatly dressed but uninvited to 11 weddings in Arizona where he stole cash and checks from envelopes given to the newlyweds, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: A Blood Feud in West Virginia Involves a Familiar Figure: Trump
description: The incumbent-on-incumbent Republican primary between Representatives Alex Mooney and David McKinley on Tuesday will again test the former president’s grip on the G.O.P.
content: The Republican-on-Republican blood feud developing in West Virginia is only over a single House seat, but the outcome of Tuesday’s primary between Representatives David McKinley and Alex Mooney will signal the direction of a potential Republican majority in Congress: Will it be a party of governance or one purely of ideology, driven by former President Donald J. Trump?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Breeders’ and ‘The Time Traveler’s Wife’
description: The third season of a dark comedy with Martin Freeman and Daisy Haggard begins on FX, and HBO debuts a new adaptation of a best-selling novel.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, May 9-15. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Mets and Yankees Split Doubleheaders on a Busy Sunday
description: Max Scherzer’s winning streak finally ended for the Mets in a loss to the Phillies and the Yankees began a stretch in which they do not have a day off until Memorial Day.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Pete Alonso homered twice, had three hits and drove in five runs to lead the Mets to a 6-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies in the second game for a doubleheader split Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: The Apartment Is Affordable, but the Neighborhood Sure Isn’t
description: A woman had a low-enough income to qualify for a HUD-sponsored apartment in Southampton, but then she went to the grocery store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Art and Mochi From the Los Angeles Nonprofit Active Cultures
description: The creative kit comes with a plate by Glenn Kaino, recipes, rice flour and access to a talk between the chef Minh Phan and Robin Koda, a rice farmer.
content: Art in the form of meal kits is the latest from Active Cultures, a Los Angeles-based nonprofit that brings art and food programming to the public. Called Home Assembly, the limited-edition kit, available through this summer until sold out, has of a plate in the style of Daruma (a Japanese symbol of perseverance and luck often on a doll), 10.78 inches in diameter, by Glenn Kaino; three recipes for mochi by Minh Phan, the chef and an owner of Phenakite; sweet rice and mochiko rice flour from Koda Farms in Dos Palos, Calif.; and a QR code to access a conversation between Ms. Phan and Robin Koda, an owner of Koda Farms. The proceeds support public arts programs by Active Cultures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: When are the Tony Awards?
description: This year’s Tony Awards ceremony will take place on Sunday, June 12.
content: This year’s Tony Awards ceremony will take place on Sunday, June 12.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: A Cook Who Never Used a Cookbook Now Has Her Own
description: Emily Meggett, the keeper of centuries-old culinary traditions in the Carolinas, has spent her life feeding others. At 89, she shares her kitchen wisdom.
content: EDISTO ISLAND, S.C. — When Emily Meggett drives you around this island in the heart of South Carolina’s Lowcountry, you don’t pay for a thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: The Tony nominations are being announced this morning. Here’s how to watch.
description: This year’s Tony Awards nominations, honoring work on Broadway as the industry tries to bounce back after the long coronavirus shutdown, are being announced at 9 a.m. Eastern today.
content: This year’s Tony Awards nominations, honoring work on Broadway as the industry tries to bounce back after the long coronavirus shutdown, are being announced at 9 a.m. Eastern today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: Woven Accessories With a Bohemian Flair
description: Crochet, raffia and leather fishnet add a carefree touch to vacation bags and shoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Russia’s invasion upends a shared World War II history with Ukraine.
description: The war has complicated relationships between Russians and Ukrainians.
content: She carried a simple bouquet of white lilacs as explosions reverberated through the bright spring air. Tears streaked her weathered face, which was framed by a blue head scarf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: U.S. to Lift Tariffs on Ukrainian Steel
description: The Biden administration will lift a 25 percent tariff on the Ukrainian steel sector for one year to help the country’s economy.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration announced on Monday that it would lift tariffs on Ukrainian steel for one year, halting a measure that President Donald J. Trump placed on that country and many others in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In Elif Batuman’s ‘Either/Or,’ a Witty and Perceptive Young Woman Returns
description: Batuman’s follow-up to “The Idiot” follows the same character into her second year at Harvard.
content: Elif Batuman’s first two books, “The Possessed,” a memoir, and “The Idiot,” a novel, took their titles from Dostoyevsky. The title of her second novel, “Either/Or,” is on loan from Kierkegaard. Batuman has a gift for making the universe seem, somehow, like the benevolent and witty literary seminar you wish it were.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: ‘Heartstopper’ Is a TV Love Story With the Soul of a Comic
description: This faithful Netflix adaptation of a popular webcomic and graphic novel tells a heartwarming boy-meets-boy tale through live action and animation.
content: Nick, 16, and Charlie, 15, sit side by side on the couch, watching a movie. Charlie has fallen asleep, arm outstretched, palm facing upward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Mooj Zadie, Kaitlin Roberts, Marc Georges, Mike Benoist, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: The Unseen Trauma of America’s Drone Pilots
description: Killing targets in remote attacks has had a deep and troubling effect on those who fly the missions.
content: This episode contains descriptions of suicide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Rachel Sherman
title: Most Broadway theaters have ended vaccination checks as coronavirus cases are rising.
description: A man had his photo I.D. out and in his hand as walked up to the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater on Broadway to see “Come From Away,” but no one checked it. The families streaming in to see “The Lion King” were told to have their tickets out and their masks on, but there was no mention of vaccine cards. And the Covid safety officers in neon yellow vests who used to patrol outside “Six” were gone.
content: A man had his photo I.D. out and in his hand as walked up to the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater on Broadway to see “Come From Away,” but no one checked it. The families streaming in to see “The Lion King” were told to have their tickets out and their masks on, but there was no mention of vaccine cards. And the Covid safety officers in neon yellow vests who used to patrol outside “Six” were gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin, Amy Chang Chien and Isabelle Qian
title: ‘We Are Now Moving From Zero Covid’: Taiwan Pivots as Beijing Doubles Down
description: The government’s shift reflects a recognition that stringent pandemic measures were stifling economic activity and eroding the island’s international competitiveness.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Until recently, China and Taiwan were among the last places on earth to pursue a “zero Covid” policy of eliminating infections. For two years, they mostly succeeded in keeping the coronavirus out with tough border controls and rigorous contact tracing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The History of Zabar’s, With Family Photos and Recipes
description: Lori Zabar, who died in February, details her family’s roots in Ukraine, the opening of their New York appetizing store and beyond.
content: Inside “Zabar’s: A Family Story, with Recipes,” there’s a family tree for the deli dynasty from 1870 to the present. Lori Zabar, the author and family historian who died in February, provides a map of Ukraine, showing Ostropol, where the Zabarkas were rooted before emigrating to America and shortening their name. Ms. Zabar, a lawyer and art historian, recounts the relative comfort the Zabarkas enjoyed in Ukraine as well as the antisemitic atrocities they suffered. She recounts their arrival in New York and the establishment of their Jewish-style appetizing store in 1934, along with family photos and a rich cityscape of the ever-evolving Upper West Side. Ms. Zabar describes the foods and other items sold at Zabar’s and the employees that sell them, and gives family recipes for Jewish staples like chopped liver and blintzes. The foreword is by The Times’s Julia Moskin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: Her Rash Wouldn’t Go Away, and the Itch Was Ruining Her Life
description: Nights were a particular torment, and nothing but steroids seemed to help. What could be causing this?
content: The itch always felt worse at night. The 68-year-old woman willed herself to lie still and not give in to the urge to scrape her skin from her body. She often wore thick cotton gloves to protect herself from her own nails. And it helped — until she tore the gloves off to scratch the itch that tortured her arms, her belly, her legs and especially her feet. She shifted restlessly on the foldout sofa where she now slept to spare her husband her incessant movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: In ‘American Song Contest,’ It’s About the Songs, Not Just the Lungs
description: Ahead of this week’s final round, a writer and photographer went backstage for this state-versus-state competition based on Eurovision. The singers get it. Does America?
content: LOS ANGELES — Backstage at a live broadcast of NBC’s “American Song Contest” last week, the crooner Michael Bolton looked relaxed as ever. He was well aware, though, that he was the odd contestant out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
title: In Blow to Ruling Family, Sri Lanka’s Prime Minister Quits in Face of Unrest
description: The move by Mahinda Rajapaksa came after his supporters instigated violent clashes in Colombo, the capital. It wasn’t immediately clear whether his resignation would satisfy opponents.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Sri Lanka’s prime minister, Mahinda Rajapaksa, resigned on Monday with his country in economic free fall, bowing to months of protests in a significant blow to the fortunes of a family dynasty that has dominated the island’s politics for nearly two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: QAnon Joins Vigilantes at the Southern Border
description: Far-right activists are intercepting migrant children and collecting information about their families, based on a conspiracy theory that they are falling prey to sex-trafficking rings.
content: SASABE, Ariz. — The 15 migrant children, weary and hungry, stumbled toward a gap in the rust-colored border wall that soars between Mexico and Arizona, nearing the end of their two-week trek north. Unexpectedly, a man in a cap emblazoned with a blackened American flag — traditionally, a message that “no quarter” will be given to the enemy — approached them and coaxed them to his campsite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: ‘‘It’s not over yet’’: Way ahead in early counting, Ferdinand Marcos Jr. remains cautious.
description: MANILA — Ferdinand Marcos Jr., the son and namesake of the ousted dictator, edged closer to a triumph in the presidential election in the Philippines on Monday as early election data shared by the government put him in a commanding lead over Leni Robredo, his closest rival.
content: MANILA — Ferdinand Marcos Jr., the son and namesake of the ousted dictator, edged closer to a triumph in the presidential election in the Philippines on Monday as early election data shared by the government put him in a commanding lead over Leni Robredo, his closest rival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Everdeen Mason
title: A Note About Today’s Wordle Game
description: At New York Times Games, we take our role seriously as a place to entertain and escape, and we want Wordle to remain distinct from the news.
content: It’s been just over three months since The New York Times acquired Wordle, the hugely popular puzzle created by Josh Wardle. Wordle continues to delight millions of people every day, but as we move it over to The Times’s technology, we have continued to discover challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Valeriya Safronova
title: In Europe’s Schoolyards, Putin’s War Hurts Russian-Speaking Children
description: Across the continent, pupils face bullying, harassment and humiliation over the invasion of Ukraine, another perverse effect of a war that is overwhelmingly affecting the innocent.
content: In a suburb of Aachen, in the west of Germany, Alex Ebert, 11, was on the bus back from school, his mother said, when four boys told him that he was killing Ukrainian children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Illinois College to Close, Hurt by Pandemic and Ransomware Attack
description: The historically Black Lincoln College will cease operations Friday after 157 years, having failed to raise millions to recover from the pandemic and a cyberattack that originated in Iran.
content: Lincoln College, a historically Black college in Illinois, will close this week after 157 years, saying it could not survive the financial challenges of the coronavirus pandemic and a ransomware attack last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: In New York, Two Ascending Political Stars Collide
description: Mayor Eric Adams and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, who represent divergent wings of the fractured Democratic Party, have not spoken one-on-one in nearly a year.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at the rift between Mayor Eric Adams and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. They have not spoken one-on-one in nearly a year. We’ll also get some fashion advice from the jazz bassist Ron Carter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: What happens next?
description: Once the nominations have been announced, the spotlight shifts to the voters.
content: Once the nominations have been announced, the spotlight shifts to the voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Islanders Fire Coach Barry Trotz After Missing N.H.L. Playoffs
description: In a surprising move, the team president, Lou Lamoriello, said the club needed “a new voice.” The Islanders made the conference finals in the previous two seasons.
content: The Islanders were one of the most disappointing teams in the N.H.L. this season, and Barry Trotz paid the price with unexpected finality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Three Races to Watch in California’s June Primary
description: Californians will start receiving ballots this week to cast their votes for governor, attorney general and more.
content: With a little less than a month until the statewide primary election, Californians will start receiving ballots in the mail this week to cast their votes for governor, senator, secretary of state and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: In Comedy, Timing Is Everything, Especially at Netflix’s Festival
description: Planned long before the streamer hit a rough patch, the expansive event had the feel of the end of an era. Still, there were plenty of stellar shows.
content: LOS ANGELES — Over the past two weeks, in a shock-and-awe display of cultural power that suddenly seems from a bygone era, Netflix put on a behemoth festival that summoned all corners of the comedy world. Take Saturday evening, for instance. Amy Poehler and Tina Fey cracked jokes at the YouTube Theater while Billy Eichner hosted an evening of LGBTQ+ stand-ups at the Greek Theater that included, among others, Wanda Sykes and Tig Notaro. Tim Heidecker chatted with comics at the Elysian Theater, a savvy new alternative space, while Mitra Jouhari from Adult Swim’s “Three Busy Debras” prepared to go onstage. Two miles away, Gabriel Iglesias was getting ready to be the first stand-up to ever perform at Dodger Stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: May 9, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, May 9, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: These Mushrooms Borrowed the Same Deadly Toxin From a Mysterious Source
description: Instead of evolving to produce poison, some distantly related fungi became toxic through a process called horizontal gene transfer, scientists say.
content: Three mushrooms known as the destroying angel, the deadly dapperling and the funeral bell all have something in common: the fabulously lethal toxin alpha-Amanitin. If you eat one of these mushrooms, symptoms may not appear for several hours. But soon enough, the toxin begins wreaking havoc on your body’s ability to transcribe genes. By the fourth day or so after consumption, your liver and kidneys begin to fail. After about a week, you may well die.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Leni Robredo, the only woman seeking the presidency, receives a groundswell of support from the young.
description: “Generation Z” and thousands of millennial voters drew inspiration from her effort to take on Ferdinand Marcos Jr.
content: One of the biggest surprises in the Philippines’ presidential election has been the groundswell of “Generation Z” and millennial support for Leni Robredo, the current vice president — and an outspoken critic of the president she served under, Rodrigo Duterte. Many of those supporters are first-time voters, or are too young to vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noa Avishag Schnall
title: A Woman Alone in Oman: Three Weeks Along the Arabian Coast
description: In December, a photographer set off on a 2,600-mile road trip, traveling from the Yemeni border to the Strait of Hormuz. Here’s what she saw.
content: I could barely tell where the salt ended and the sky began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Askarinam
title: What We’re Watching For in the Nebraska and West Virginia Primaries
description: Republican voters in the two states will choose nominees for governor and the House in races that pit Trump-backed candidates against rivals supported by each state’s governor.
content: Two states are holding primary elections on Tuesday. In one, Joe Biden couldn’t crack 40 percent of the vote in 2020; in the other, he couldn’t even get to 30 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Tell Us About Your Chosen Family
description: For Pride this year, The Times wants to hear from those who identify as L.G.B.T. about finding kinship and strength outside traditional family structures.
content: In honor of Pride Month this June, The Times is collecting stories about chosen families in the L.G.B.T. community. The term comes from anthropological literature and refers to the intense, intimate relationships some L.G.B.T. people form apart from their biological relatives; it is the kinship you create outside of a traditional family structure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: ‘Wedding Band,’ a Searing Look at Miscegenation Nation
description: Alice Childress’s 1962 play about interracial love and hate gets its first major New York revival in 50 years.
content: The first thing you see upon taking your seat at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn is a worn-out double bed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Get Ready for the New, Improved Second’
description: In this lesson, students will learn how scientists have redefined the standard unit of time. Then, they will create a children’s book explaining different units.
content: Featured Article: “Get Ready for the New, Improved Second” by Alanna Mitchell
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Sizing Up the Decisions of Older Adults
description: A new training tool helps to assess whether some seniors can make informed choices about their own care and well-being.
content: During a recent Zoom conference call, four Adult Protective Services workers from California, using a tool called the Interview for Decisional Abilities, or IDA, were trying to figure out whether something fishy was going on with an 82-year-old woman they knew as Ms. K.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Waite
title: The Perfect Daughter Vanished on Prom Night. The Question Is: Why?
description: In Casey McQuiston’s Y.A. debut, “I Kissed Shara Wheeler,” a queer teenage rebel is on the hunt to find her school’s missing golden girl, who, it turns out, is hiding a few secrets.
content: Teenage crime or teenage love — it’s anyone’s guess which has more potential to ruin lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Labour Leader Pledges to Resign if Police Find He Broke Covid Rules
description: But Keir Starmer maintained that he was within the law when he had a beer with takeout food during a campaign meeting last year.
content: LONDON — The scandal over lockdown-breaking parties that has ensnared Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain took a new turn on Monday when his rival, the opposition leader Keir Starmer, promised to resign if police decide that he also broke coronavirus laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: Ecuador Prison Riot Leaves Dozens Dead
description: The riot in northern Ecuador left at least 40 inmates dead and more than a dozen injured. It’s the latest blood bath inside the country’s troubled and overcrowded prison system.
content: MEXICO CITY — At least 40 inmates were killed in a prison riot in northern Ecuador on Monday, according to the authorities, the latest in a series of bloody clashes inside the South American nation’s violent detention system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriel Winant and Theresa Brown
title: When Health Care Workers Are Protected, Patients Are, Too
description: Why health care needs labor peace agreements.
content: America was in a health care crisis before Covid, and the stresses of the pandemic have made it worse. Since the pandemic began, the health care work force — the country’s largest industry by employment — has shrunk by nearly 2 percent. That may seem like a small amount, but historically, the health care work force doesn’t shrink; it only grows. Now, with astronomical turnover and rising demand as patients seek care that they may have put off during the height of the pandemic, hospitals, clinics, nursing homes and home care agencies across the country lack sufficient staff members to adequately care for patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: Why Heart Disease in Women Is So Often Missed or Dismissed
description: New research shows that women may not realize their symptoms point to heart trouble, and that medical providers aren’t picking up on it either.
content: Heart disease is the leading cause of death among men and women in America, killing nearly 700,000 people a year. But studies have long shown that women are more likely than men to dismiss the warning signs of a heart attack, sometimes waiting hours or longer to call 911 or go to a hospital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: Handel’s ‘Serse,’ With Yuks and Exquisite Playing
description: The English Concert’s performance at Carnegie Hall showed off the ensemble’s elastic responsiveness.
content: If you eat up Baroque shtick, as I do, the English Concert’s presentation of Handel’s “Serse” at Carnegie Hall on Sunday was probably right up your alley. Those with more rarefied taste were likely satisfied too, as the conductor Harry Bicket and his ensemble of early-music players offered up a surfeit of exquisite music-making.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Beinart
title: Biden Could Make the World Safer, but He’s Too Afraid of the Politics
description: The administration knows how to get the Iran nuclear deal back. It’s just afraid of Republicans.
content: President Biden has the chance to avert a nuclear crisis that could push the United States to the brink of war and threaten the coalition he’s built to counter Russia. But he isn’t seizing it for one overriding reason: He fears the political blowback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Dana Rubinstein
title: Taxpayers May Foot Bill for Penn Station Revitalization, Report Says
description: New York State wants to rebuild the transit hub in Midtown Manhattan and pay for the improvements through a larger real estate development.
content: To restore the ailing Pennsylvania Station, both Gov. Kathy Hochul and her predecessor endorsed an extraordinary reimagining of Midtown Manhattan with 10 super-tall skyscrapers — among the largest real estate projects in American history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Appease or Confront
description: It’s Victory Day in Russia — a holiday honoring World War II that has long been important to Vladimir Putin.
content: For much of the past two decades, the U.S. and its European allies have chosen not to confront Vladimir Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Safety Lapses Cited in South Dakota Plane Crash That Killed 9
description: Newly released documents about the 2019 crash revealed that the pilot failed to completely remove ice from the wings before takeoff, and that the plane was overloaded with passengers.
content: Newly released details about a 2019 plane crash that killed nine of 12 members of an Idaho family revealed that a buildup of snow and ice on the wings and other parts of the plane played a significant role in the crash shortly after takeoff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Pulitzer Prize: 2022 Winners List
description: Here’s the full list of winners and finalists.
content: The Pulitzer committee honored The Post with the prestigious public service award for its “compellingly told and vividly presented account of the assault on Washington on Jan. 6, 2021.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina, Alyssa Lukpat and Christine Chung
title: Alabama Officer Dies and Escapee Is Caught After Crash, Officials Say
description: The authorities had been searching since April 29 for the corrections officer and the inmate, who they had said were in a “special relationship.” The inmate surrendered after a police pursuit in Indiana, and the officer fatally shot herself, the authorities said.
content: A national manhunt for a corrections officer and the Alabama inmate she helped to escape last month ended Monday after a police pursuit resulted in a crash in Indiana, the authorities said. The inmate surrendered, and the officer fatally shot herself, they said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James B. Stewart
title: A Violin From Hollywood’s Golden Age Aims at an Auction Record
description: Played in “The Wizard of Oz” and other classic films, Toscha Seidel’s Stradivarius could sell for almost $20 million.
content: Rare violins once owned by famed virtuosos like Fritz Kreisler, Jascha Heifetz and Yehudi Menuhin have sold privately in recent years for up to $20 million. The instruments they played typically bear their names, like the “Earl of Plymouth” Stradivarius, which to burnish its reputation, mystique and market value is now also referred to as the “ex-Kreisler.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Erling Haaland Appears Set to Join Manchester City
description: City, which is nearing its fourth Premier League title in five years, would be strengthened further by adding Haaland, the 21-year-old Dortmund striker.
content: Manchester City appears to have won the race to sign striker Erling Haaland, with multiple published reports indicating that the 21-year-old Norwegian goal-scoring machine will be the latest addition to a star-studded roster that is on the cusp of winning its fourth Premier League title in five years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Camille Elemia
title: Voters complain of broken machines and long waits.
description: MANILA — Millions of Filipinos stood in line for hours on Monday to pick a new leader to replace President Rodrigo Duterte in the most consequential election that the Philippines has seen in more than three decades.
content: MANILA — Millions of Filipinos stood in line for hours on Monday to pick a new leader to replace President Rodrigo Duterte in the most consequential election that the Philippines has seen in more than three decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden signs bill to allow lending arms to Ukraine, which will speed up shipments.
description: The law will waive time-consuming requirements on the provision of arms to Ukraine considered critical to its defense against Russian forces.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Monday signed an updated version of the Lend-Lease Act that supplied Britain and eventually other allies during World War II, summoning the spirit of the last century’s epic battle for democracy as he paved the way for further arms shipments to Ukrainians fighting to repel Russian invaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson and Scott Heller
title: There were Tony snubs and surprises, as always.
description: Several stars, including Daniel Craig and Sarah Jessica Parker, were not nominated for their performances, while “Paradise Square” became one of the season’s most-nominated shows.
content: Tony nominations morning is always filled with joy for lots of performers, theater artists and producers who find themselves in contention for Broadway’s biggest recognition. But there are also always some who are overlooked, and others who are just gobsmacked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Rob Manfred and M.L.B. Seek Consistency on Baseballs
description: The baseball commissioner said the league was working to ensure balls performed the same at all parks. Humidors and gripping agents are part of that plan.
content: Commissioner Rob Manfred is well aware that his league’s baseballs are under scrutiny from players, fans and others, and while Major League Baseball is working to address various issues, his message on the subject has a central theme: consistency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristin-Lee Moolman and Jacob K
title: Bold Fashion That Offers a Chance to Try On a New Identity
description: This season, why not adopt a highly tailored look — or pair silk with faux fur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Candied Morels Are a Spring Treat
description: Take a sweeter approach with the honeycomb fungi, now in season, by cooking them in sugar and serving with ice cream or foie gras.
content: On a 2019 trip to Northern Greece, lunch at Kanela & Garyfallo Restaurant, in Zagori, ended with a memorable dessert of candied chanterelles and thick Greek yogurt. It came to mind when Angie Mar recently served a savory foie gras mille-feuille garnished with candied morels (morilles confites) at her restaurant, Les Trois Chevaux, in the West Village. The morels, now in season, couldn’t be simpler to prepare; serve them over vanilla ice cream, or Greek yogurt. Melt one and a half cups sugar over medium heat in a heavy-bottomed, three-quart saucepan until it turns light amber. Carefully add 12 ounces hot water, slowly stirring because it may bubble up; cook until the sugar dissolves. Add five ounces rinsed fresh morels and a half teaspoon salt and simmer about 10 minutes until the mushrooms start to look translucent. Refrigerate, covered, until ready to use; save the liquid to enrich onion soup or use as a poaching liquid for pears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Turbow
title: King of Throws
description: Tom House rebuilt Nolan Ryan and fixed Randy Johnson. He worked with Tom Brady and Drew Brees. At 75, he has reinvented himself (again) with an app that teaches young players to pitch the right way.
content: When most of the world first became familiar with Tom House, he was catching Hank Aaron’s record-breaking 715th homer in 1974. House, then a relief pitcher for Atlanta, was stationed in the bullpen beyond the left-field fence at Fulton County Stadium, just where the ball happened to come down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Paula Vogel on ‘How I Learned to Drive’ nominations: ‘I’m just thrilled.’
description: Twenty-five years after it was a hit Off Broadway, the playwright’s Pulitzer Prize-winning work debuted on Broadway this season.
content: The playwright Paula Vogel was first nominated for a Tony in 2017, for “Indecent.” Now she has a second Tony nomination for “How I Learned to Drive,” which she wrote in two weeks, 25 years ago. A play about abuse, love and survival, it interrogates the relationship between Uncle Peck and his underage niece, Li’l Bit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Two political clans with an autocratic past seek power together.
description: Two of the Philippines’ most powerful political families have joined forces in the May 9 elections as the children of two presidents seek the country’s top offices.
content: Two of the Philippines’ most powerful political families have joined forces in the May 9 elections as the children of two presidents seek the country’s top offices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: In Speech, Putin Shows Reluctance in Demanding Too Much of Russians
description: The Russian president, in a much-anticipated speech on his country’s most important holiday, did not proclaim an escalation of the fight in Ukraine.
content: He made no claim of victory or “mission accomplished” and no promise that the fight in Ukraine could end soon. But as President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia spoke in Moscow’s Red Square on Monday, he also made no call for new sacrifice or mobilization, no threat of a nuclear strike, no stark pronouncement about an existential war with the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: The Rift Between A.O.C. and Eric Adams: When Democratic Stars Collide
description: Mayor Adams and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, who represent divergent wings of the Democratic Party, have not spoken one-on-one in nearly a year.
content: Last July, shortly after his win in New York City’s Democratic primary for mayor, Eric Adams traveled to Washington for a customary visit with members of the state’s congressional delegation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Queen Elizabeth to Miss Opening of Parliament
description: Prince Charles will deliver the Queen’s Speech instead of his mother, who has missed the constitutional monarchy’s powerful symbol only twice in 70 years.
content: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II will not preside over the state opening of Britain’s Parliament on Tuesday, Buckingham Palace said Monday evening, the first time she has missed the ceremony since 1963 and a stark sign that health problems are forcing the indomitable, but increasingly frail, monarch to fade from public view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Former Heads of State Urge U.S. to Commit $5 Billion to Global Covid Fight
description: Activists are also pressing President Biden to take a more forceful leadership role in the response as he convenes world leaders for a Covid-19 summit on Thursday.
content: WASHINGTON — A group of former heads of state and Nobel laureates are calling on the United States to immediately commit $5 billion to combat the global coronavirus pandemic, and activists are pressing President Biden to take a more forceful leadership role in the response as he convenes world leaders for a Covid-19 summit on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: At Start of Mario Batali Trial, Accuser Details Unwanted Groping and Kissing
description: Proceedings began Monday for the celebrity chef on charges that he assaulted a young woman in a Boston bar.
content: The woman who has accused the celebrity chef Mario Batali of groping her at a Boston bar in April 2017 spent several contentious hours testifying on Monday, the opening day of his criminal trial on charges of indecent battery and assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: The coronavirus posed a special challenge to the Tony nominators.
description: The pandemic has made this comeback theater season an unusually rocky one. After a joyous reopening following the long, painful shutdown, the Omicron surge led to a ton of holiday closings, and another spike in positive cases this spring led to a rolling wave of performer absences and occasional show cancellations.
content: The pandemic has made this comeback theater season an unusually rocky one. After a joyous reopening following the long, painful shutdown, the Omicron surge led to a ton of holiday closings, and another spike in positive cases this spring led to a rolling wave of performer absences and occasional show cancellations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Susan Jaffe to Be Next Artistic Director at American Ballet Theater
description: A former star ballerina with the company, Jaffe will assume the reins after the 30-year tenure of Kevin McKenzie.
content: Susan Jaffe, a former American Ballet Theater ballerina, will become the artistic director of that company when Kevin McKenzie steps down after a 30-year tenure, at the end of 2022, the company announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Skolnick
title: A Free Diver’s Training Partners: Sharks
description: Competitive free divers aim to go as deep as possible. But fun dives, even extreme ones, have always been intrinsic to the sport. Denis Grosmaire would know.
content: It was another perfect February morning off the coral atoll of Tikehau, French Polynesia, when Denis Grosmaire, 44, anchored around 8 in the morning. Grosmaire, French Polynesia’s deepest free diver, peered over the edge into the crystal-clear South Pacific Ocean. On one side of his speedboat was a flourishing coral reef that plunged toward the shadowy depths. On the other was endless blue water. He slipped on a pair of fins, dropped in alone and waited for company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Susan Rice, a White House adviser, tests positive for the coronavirus.
description: Ms. Rice said she had last seen President Biden in person on Wednesday while wearing a mask and that, according to the C.D.C. guidelines, he was “not considered a close contact.”
content: Susan Rice, the White House domestic policy adviser, has become the latest member of the Biden administration to report testing positive for the coronavirus, announcing Monday on Twitter that she had received the result this morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Match Group sues Google over its app store rules.
description: The owner of the dating services Tinder and OkCupid claims Google violated antitrust laws.
content: Match Group, which owns dating services like Tinder and OkCupid, sued Google on Monday, claiming that it broke antitrust laws with the rules it set for its smartphone app store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dylan Loeb McClain
title: Yuri Averbakh, Chess’s First Centenarian Grandmaster, Dies at 100
description: A Russian, he was one of the world’s best players during the Cold War of the 1950s, joining other top competitors as the pride of the Soviet Union.
content: Yuri Averbakh, a Russian chess grandmaster who was among the world’s best players for a decade, trained world champions and was the last surviving participant in one of the greatest competitions in history, died on Saturday in Moscow. He was 100 — the first grandmaster ever to reach that age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Genoways
title: How Trump Helped Transform Nebraska Into a Toxic Political Wasteland
description: The state has a long tradition of workaday populism and civil bipartisanship, but in just a few years, it has moved swiftly to the right.
content: LINCOLN, Neb. — In the old days, Charles W. Herbster, a cattle baron and bull semen tycoon who used his fortune and influence to get into Donald Trump’s good graces, almost certainly would have been forced to pull out of Nebraska’s Republican primary for governor by now. In recent weeks, eight women, including a state senator, have come forward to allege that Mr. Herbster groped them at various Republican events or at beauty pageants at which he was a judge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Future Earns an Eighth No. 1 Album With ‘I Never Liked You’
description: The Atlanta rapper’s latest release had the largest numbers of the year so far, but big new LPs from Bad Bunny and Jack Harlow will register on next week’s chart.
content: For most of the year so far, sales of new music have been pretty unremarkable, with even the No. 1 album posting modest numbers week after week. But those doldrums may now be over, with a hit new LP by the rapper Future and a slew of high-profile releases coming — including a surprise release by the Puerto Rican superstar Bad Bunny that is poised to make a big splash on next week’s chart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Medication Abortions Are Increasing: What They Are and Where Women Get Them
description: Most abortions overseas involve pills, and the method is used in about half of legal U.S. abortions. It also seems to be the future of illicit abortion.
content: Taking pills to end a pregnancy accounts for a growing share of abortions in the United States, both legal and not. If the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade as expected, medication abortion will play a larger role, especially among women who lose access to abortion clinics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Macron Calls for ‘Stronger’ Europe but Quashes Ukraine’s Hopes of Joining E.U. Soon
description: French president Emmanuel Macron spoke in Strasbourg and Berlin on Monday, outlining proposals to reform the European Union.
content: PARIS — French President Emmanuel Macron used a much-anticipated address to the European Parliament on Monday to sketch out his vision for the future of the European Union, calling for a “stronger and more sovereign” Europe, even as he dashed Ukraine’s hopes of joining the 27-nation E.U. bloc any time soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: Reports of violence and broken voting machines in the Philippines leave voters on edge.
description: Security was tight for this election, a particularly high-stakes contest that some observers have called an existential battle for the soul of the nation.
content: MANILA — Election violence erupted in the Philippines over the weekend and on Monday after a shooting between two groups linked to rivals for mayor left four people dead, and a grenade attack wounded nine others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: A bomb-sniffing dog named Patron received state honors from Zelensky.
description: Patron has found more than 200 explosives, President Zelensky said. The dog has gone viral as Ukraine wages an information war.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky has routinely ended his nightly wartime addresses by announcing state awards for Ukraine’s soldiers. On Sunday, he honored a fighter who is perhaps the country’s smallest — a little dog named Patron.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Sometimes, History Goes Backward
description: The seeming demise of Roe v. Wade is only part of the story.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I don’t know if you remember the Lloyd Bridges character from the movie “Airplane,” the guy who keeps saying, “Looks like I picked the wrong week to quit smoking/drinking/amphetamines/sniffing glue.” We were away last week and … stuff happened. Your thoughts on what appears to be the imminent demise of Roe v. Wade?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: On an Endangered River, Another Toxic Disaster Is Waiting to Happen
description: Waste from coal plants is threatening the Mobile-Tensaw Delta, which the biologist E.O. Wilson called “arguably the biologically richest place” in the nation.
content: NASHVILLE — Almost four years ago, spurred by my decades-long fascination with Homer’s story of the lotus-eaters, my husband and I made a pilgrimage to the Mobile-Tensaw Delta in Alabama to see American lotuses in full bloom. Jimbo Meador, our guide, was happy to take us on his boat to see the extravagant flowers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: The Pulitzer Prize Winner That Emerged Out of a Time of Quietness
description: Raven Chacon’s “Voiceless Mass,” a work for ensemble and pipe organ that “evokes the weight of history in a church setting,” won the prize for music.
content: At the height of the coronavirus pandemic, when the world around him turned quiet and still, the composer Raven Chacon went to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: It’s the most consequential election in the Philippines in recent history.
description: MANILA — Filipinos headed to the polls on Monday in a hotly contested election that has been described as the most consequential in decades, one that will shape the direction of the country’s fragile democracy and transform alliances with the United States and China.
content: MANILA — Filipinos headed to the polls on Monday in a hotly contested election that has been described as the most consequential in decades, one that will shape the direction of the country’s fragile democracy and transform alliances with the United States and China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: What to expect from this year’s nominations.
description: Here’s what to expect today:
content: Here’s what to expect today:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: James Ijames on Winning a Pulitzer and Making ‘Hamlet’ a Comedy
description: The 41-year-old playwright’s show “Fat Ham,” set at a Southern barbecue, hasn’t even had an in-person production yet because of the pandemic.
content: The play “Fat Ham,” a comedic riff on “Hamlet” set at a Southern barbecue, hasn’t even had an in-person production yet because of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Strong Winds Fuel Wildfires in New Mexico
description: “We can’t plead enough: Heed evacuations,” the National Weather Service said, echoing orders given by local authorities.
content: Strong winds and unusually high temperatures were expected to continue to fuel wildfires on Monday in New Mexico, where several fires, including one of the largest in the state’s history, were encroaching on communities and prompting evacuations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Explore the Corners of the Wine World With Raw Wine Club
description: Monthly subscription boxes come with six bottles and tasting notes from Isabelle Legeron, the first female Master of Wine in France.
content: “Raw wine” is an appropriate label for the category of natural, low-intervention, biodynamic and organic wines, that is wines not made using conventional methods. Isabelle Legeron, the first female Master of Wine in France and an authority on the wines, has created the Raw Wine Club. Subscriptions, each with six bottles and Ms. Legeron’s tasting notes, are $199 a month (including shipping); they ship to most states and are usually available until the end of a month for delivery the following month. Some of the choices for April were Palmento Vino Rosso 2020 from Sicily, Umberto 2020 from Piedmont, and Ancestral Blanc 2019 from the Loire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Does Prayer Have Any Place in Public Schools?
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments about a football coach who was told to stop offering prayers publicly after games. What impact will the case have on the role of religion in schools?
content: In the landmark case Engel v. Vitale in 1962, the Supreme Court ruled that school-sponsored prayer in public schools violated the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment — breaching the constitutional wall of separation between church and state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Cortes Loses No-Hit Bid in 8th, but Yankees Rally to Win
description: In a breakout season that continues to thrill, Nestor Cortes got a no-decision for his 11-strikeout masterpiece.
content: Nestor Cortes may be the least-heralded top starting pitcher in the major leagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: New York Lawmakers Push for Abortion Fund to Establish ‘Safe Harbor’
description: Lawmakers in Albany are considering a range of options to expand abortion rights in New York, as many other states prepare to restrict them.
content: Even before the Supreme Court decided Roe v. Wade in 1973, establishing a constitutional right to abortion across the country, New York was a destination for women seeking the procedure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Hungary?
description: Can you find Hungary on a map? What else do you know about this European country with nearly 10 million people?
content: Can you find Hungary on a map? What else do you know about this European country with nearly 10 million people?
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Hotly Contested Election in the Philippines
description: Filipinos headed to the polls on Monday in a hotly contested election that has been described as the most consequential in decades, one that will shape the direction of the country's fragile democracy.

title: $1 Million Homes in California
description: A storybook house in Fullerton, a midcentury ranch in Calistoga and a three-bedroom condominium unit in Los Angeles.
content: A storybook house in Fullerton, a midcentury ranch in Calistoga and a three-bedroom condominium unit in Los Angeles.

author: By Network Pool
title: Jill Biden Says She Told President Biden of the ‘Horrors’ in Ukraine
description: Dr. Jill Biden, the first lady, told reporters at the presidential palace in Slovakia that she had called President Biden and urged him to continue supporting Ukraine.
content: Dr. Jill Biden, the first lady, told reporters at the presidential palace in Slovakia that she had called President Biden and urged him to continue supporting Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Signs Bill to Allow Arms Lending to Ukraine
description: President Biden signed the Ukraine Democracy Defense Lend-Lease Act, which would speed up shipments considered critical for Ukraine’s forces to repel Russian invaders.
content: President Biden signed the Ukraine Democracy Defense Lend-Lease Act, which would speed up shipments considered critical for Ukraine’s forces to repel Russian invaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Conjuring the fettuccine Alfredo from Bamonte’s, a new recipe for papadzules and more.
content: Good morning. For a long time I thought the only fettuccine Alfredo that mattered was the one served at Bamonte’s restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. I’d order it elsewhere and receive a plate of goop, but never there. Rich with heavy cream, butter and Parmesan, the sauce cloaked the pasta with a silky sheen that took well to a grind of black pepper, a pop of sharpness against the salt.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Portrait of Ed Koch’s Secret Gay Life
description: Anger, sadness and other reaction to the story about the former mayor. Also: An L.G.B.T.Q. bill; Amazon and unions; young people and change; unopened letters.
content: To the Editor:
